Technological advancements and ever-changing work policies provide people with an option to work from home, rather than the office where they meet the team face to face. List out and discuss the advantages and disadvantages of working from home?
India a sub continent is a developing country with lots of technological advancements where the literacy rate has drastically grown up from the last decade.The government of india has made a law for compulsory education to all the children in rural and urban areas.However,education without computer and technical knowledge is also considered as illeteracy.The corporate companies have also stretched their hands to educate the youth in their technical skills which is a good sign of developing india.Every student of rural and urban areas are becoming computer literate and showing their interest to learn new technological skills.India has more mobiles when compared with the washrooms that means the people are well adjusted with the techical advancements and showing intrest to work on technical jobs like software unlike the past few decades.Technological advancements have been improved with the globalization where the work culture has a tremondous change.corporate companies are providing an option for its employees to work from home,rather than the office where this work culture has advantages as well as disadvantages. 

Work from home is considered as an advantage for both the employer and employee.An emploee who works from home can do the work simultaneously taking care of the family where family relations can be maintained which gives an employee a fresh and a relaxed mind to work.The female employees can do their parenting and even feels safe and secured to work from home where there are lots of technological advancements to interact with the employers and team with video calling and video conferences.An employee has his shifts duration to work from home online where he feels comfortable and even there will be no need for the employee to take leaves and can work online.

Work from home is also beneficial to the employer as there will be less usage of power supply in the office,less transport usage can be an advantage for the employer,employee and even to the society.Their would be less manpower in the office premise where the work can be coordinated easily among the employees.Through the use of internet connection the interaction between the employees will be good and the employee can contact the manager or higher officials without any insecurity.The information system that was developed helps the employer to maintain the data of all the employees,their work progress and the process will always be authenticated without any decryption of the mediaters.Work from home will be an advantage to the employees especially to the females who feels insecured to work in the grave yard shifts for most of the us based mnc companies.It will be easy for the hr manager or the employer to judge the performance of the employee.Grievences can be resolved or overcomed through work from home process.

There are also a few disadvantages in this culture of work from home where most of the employees will be giving an option to work from home rather than office.There will be lack of coordination between the employees where the employee couldnt give up to the needs of the office.Their would also be a distractions in the family or home where the employee couldnt put all his efforts in to the work by which there will be less or unsatisfied output.employees who have less technical knowledge can not communicate with there team which results in lack of team work.team work provides best results compared to individuals which will be a disadvantage.Technical issues and connectivity problems can arise during an important meeting or discussion.

World Auto Industry Outlook - June 2013

The auto industry is highly concentrated. The top 10 global automakers account for roughly 80% of the worldwide production and nearly 90% of total vehicles sold in the U.S.

Toyota recaptured the sales crown from General Motors by selling 9.75 million vehicles globally in 2012, which exceeded GM`s sales of 9.29 million vehicles. Germany`s Volkswagen AG ( VLKAY ) came third with sales of 9.07 million vehicles for the year.

Although automakers continue to focus on shifting their production facilities to new regions driven by cost and demand factors, developing the supplier networks remains one of their greatest challenges. Existing suppliers to automakers often lack the financial strength to expand capacity in new markets. On the other hand, auto parts suppliers are sensitive to technology transfers to local third parties, which can give rise to low-cost competitors.

High dependence on automakers makes the auto market suppliers vulnerable to several maladies, primarily pricing pressure and production cuts. Pricing pressure from automakers constricts parts suppliers` margins. On the other hand, production cuts by automakers driven by frequent market adjustments negatively affect their operations.

Future of Green Cars Looks Bleak

Rising fuel prices and global warming have turned attention to the auto industry that either rely less on traditional fossil fuels or use cheaper renewable sources of energy. Despite the U.S. Government`s continued effort to promote "green" alternatives such as fuel-efficient electric vehicles (EVs) and hybrid vehicles, things look bleak, at least in the near future. Globally, the hybrid market is ruled by Toyota (which includes the Prius) and Honda (includes Civic and Insight hybrids). Meanwhile, other automakers such as Ford, General Motors and Nissan are also aggressively pursuing a plan to push hybrid sales. Some of the well-recognized "green" cars include the Ford Focus, GM Volt, Nissan Leaf and Daimler AG`s ( DDAIF ) smart USA micro EV. U.S. is the largest hybrid car market in the world with sales accounting for 60%-70% of global hybrid sales.

However, the industry has witnessed some notable adverse developments in the drive for green technology. In January 2013, the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) backed off President Barack Obama`s stated goal of putting 1 million electric cars on the road by 2015 due to weaker than expected demand for plug-ins/EVs. According to Hybridcars.com, plug-in/EV sales constituted a meager 3.3% of the overall sales in the U.S. in 2012. The weak demand for plug-ins/EVs has led some lithium-ion battery makers file for bankruptcy protection in 2012. They include MA-based A123 Systems Inc. and NY-based EnerDel, despite both being DOE grant recipients (A123 - $249.1 million; EnerDel - $118.5 million). It also led another DOE grant recipient (in fact, the third largest with $161.0 million), Dow Kokam, to be written down by chemical behemoth Dow Chemical ( DOW ), who jointly operated the entity with TK Advanced Battery LLC since 2009.
